Merge pull request #567 from CtrlZvi/module_package_name_resolution

Correctly identify package names in modules on Go 1.9+

Keep supporting Go versions < 1.9

The go/types package introduced a change in Go 1.9 (not documented in
the relese notes) that is required for golang.org/x/tools/go/packages
to compile. The previous commit's dependency on that library would
break support for Go versions < 1.9. Since those versions can't be
using modules, the old implementation using go/build will continue to
work for them. We separate the impacted functions out into two versions
that use build tags with conditional compilation to use the out of
GOPATH module supporting version in Go >= 1.9 and the old behavior in
Go < 1.9.

Correctly identify package names in modules

Currently, GoConvey uses go/build and `build.ImportDir()` to collect
information about a package, including its name. Under modules that
live outside of the GOPATH, this resolution breaks, and every module
ends up with the name ".". At the very least this breaks coverage by
causing all coverage reports to be written to client/reports.html
instead of client/reports/<opackage specific>.html.

The core issue is the go/build does not fully support modules. There
was a partial fix submitted in https://github.com/golang/go/commit/f85125345cc5d3eb054c90bfca4bda3544d7fcab,
but it only works if the package being looked up is being looked up by
name, not by path, and GoConvey somewhat necessarily uses the path. As
outlined in the above commit, the intended solution is to use the
golang.org/x/tools/go/packages which will hopefully be migrated to
go/packages in a future Go version.

Fix function comments based on best practices from Effective Go

Signed-off-by: CodeLingo Bot <bot@codelingo.io>

Merge pull request #376 from wallclockbuilder/javascript-cleanup

Javascript cleanup

Use '!==' instead of '!='. Typesafe operators FTW.

It is considered good practice to use the type-safe equality operators
=== and !== instead of their regular counterparts == and !=.

The reason for this is that == and != do type coercion which follows
the rather obscure Abstract Equality Comparison
Algorithm(http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-11.9.3).
For instance, the following statements are all considered true:

[] == false
[] == ![]
3 == "03"

If one of those occurs in an innocent-looking statement such as a == b
the actual problem is very difficult to spot.

Use type-safe equality operator '===' instead of the sloppy '=='.

It is considered good practice to use the type-safe equality operators
=== and !== instead of their regular counterparts == and !=.

The reason for this is that == and != do type coercion which follows
the rather obscure Abstract Equality Comparison
Algorithm(http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-11.9.3).
For instance, the following statements are all considered true:

    [] == false
    [] == ![]
    3 == "03"

If one of those occurs in an innocent-looking statement such as a == b
the actual problem is very difficult to spot.

Merge pull request #316 from xogeny/lookup_change

Small change to include files that end in _tests.go as external callers

Small change to include files that end in _tests.go as external callers

This change came about because of a use case where the current semantics around resolving
external callers was not ideal.  The use case was for testing interfaces.  In such cases,
the interfaces are typically stored in one package while implementations are stored
in another.  Furthermore, tests written against the interface are stored with the interfaces
but the actual tests that instantiate the implementation and call the interface tests
are stored with the implementations.  The net result of this is that GoConvey would
get confused on who the external caller was AND any files that ended in _test.go stored
with the interfaces were excluded during compilation of the implementations.  This small
change allows files ending in _tests.go to also be candidates for external callers.  The
result is that tests written against interfaces can be stored with the interfaces in
a file that ends with _tests.go and the Go compiler will, therefore, include them when
compiling the implementations...and all is well.

Merge pull request #287 from xogeny/master

Added error checks along with hints about source of error
No longer targeting go 1.1 when building on travis ci.

Trying to address build issue

The builds are failing with complains about coverage tools not being installed.  I suspect
that the lack of error checking previously either masked an existing error or intentionally
allowed failures and compensated elsewhere with other logic.  To test this, I'm reverting
once of my changes to see if it allows the build to succeed.  My fear is this will continue
to mask an error (or at least fail to clarify the expected behavior).  But even after
reverting this change, other (more important aspects, at least to me) are still addressed
by my changes.

Fixing a previously untriggered error

My previous fix started reporting errors that were previously ignored.  As a result,
this test case (which should have failed before, but didn't) started to fail.  It turns
out that the directory referenced in the test was incorrect but because the errors
were not caught previously, it seemed to pass.  Once my fix was applied, the test
failed (as it should have).  This commit corrects the directory name so the test
now passes again.

Merge pull request #264 from riannucci/nested_scope

Nested scope. Introduces dependency on github.com/jtolds/gls package. Fixes #81. Fixes #156.

Improve the internal panic messages.

Also simplify the rules for Convey-induced panics. They'll always
bubble to the top now instead of sometimes bubbling or sometimes
recovering.

Cover the case of the panic'ing reset.

Also remove comment about LIFO, since the tests already enforce
FIFO ordering of Reset's (e.g. WAI).
Remove test from context.
Use a map instead of a fixed slice ordering

Minimal fixes to reporting for nesting scopes.

Uses a quick hack to correctly obtain a 'unique' ID for scopes
in the flat map used by the JSON and story reports. A correctly
crafted Convey name could collide with a key in the map, but that
is likely to be self-sabotage.

A more elaborate solution would be to have a generic report-gatherer
tree, and then implement the various output reports as walkers over
the tree structure at the end of every story.

Merge branch 'm4rw3r-mw/failure_options'
Now using the new FailureContinues mode for the assertion wire-up tests.

Implemented failure-mode settings per Convey-block

This allows tests to optionally specify on a block-level if they
want their failing So()-assertions to block further execution of
the test arm or if they want failing So()-assertions to allow the
test-arm to proceed.

Top-level blocks default to halting execution on a So()-assertion
failure and every block inherits from its parent-block to avoid
repetition.

Brought back incrementing console statistics.

Using package-level statistics reporter (hack). Fixes #209 (just for
